original_title: Transport sector companies contribute more than one-third of CSE turnover amid profit-takings
original_body_lines: CSE activities kicked off on a positive note in early sessions yesterday but turned negative due to profit-takings in some sectors.

Both indices moved downwards. The All Share Price Index went down by 232 points, while the S and P SL20 declined by 55.04 points. Turnover stood at Rs 9.05 billion seven crossings. More than one third of the turnover was contributed by transport sector companies, it is learnt.

Those crossings were reported in Pickme, which crossed 21.4 million shares to the tune of Rs 2.8 billion and its shares traded at Rs 132, NTB 300,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 79.5 million and its shares sold at Rs 265, JKH two million shares crossed for Rs 45 million; its shares sold at Rs 22.50, Aitken Spence 200,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 30.8 million; its shares fetched Rs 154, Kotagala Plantations 3.2 million shares crossed for Rs 30.2 million; its shares traded at Rs 9.50, Sampath Bank 200,000 shares crossed for Rs 28.4 million; its shares traded at Rs 142 and Ceylinco Holdings (Non- Voting) 14000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 23.8 million; its shares sold at Rs 1700.

In the retail market top seven companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; Hatton Plantations Rs 581 million (19.3 million shares traded), Pickme Rs 266 million (two million shares traded), Aitken Spence Hotels Rs 235 million (2.16 million shares traded), LOLC Holdings Rs 214 million (382000 shares traded), Laughs Gas Rs 194 million (2.66 million shares traded), HNB Rs 191 million (497,000 shares traded) and Brown’s Investments Rs 150 million (19.6 million shares traded). During the day 238 million share volumes changed hands in 46972 transactions.

It is said that transport sector companies, especially Pickme, contributed more than one third of the turnover. Plantations sector counters too performed well. The banking and finance sector was also active due to satisfactory turnover levels. The manufacturing sector was also among the top performers.
Yesterday the rupee opened stronger to the US dollar at Rs 301.88/93 from Rs301.97/302.02 the previous day, while bond yields edged up slightly, dealers said.
A bond maturing on 01.07.2028 was quoted at 8.95/9.05 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.12.2029 was quoted at 9.52/57 percent, up from 9.51/55 percent.
A bond maturing on 01.07.2030 was quoted at 9.65/75 percent.
A bond maturing on 15.12.2032 was quoted at 10.35/45 percent, up from 10.35/43 percent.

The telegraphic transfer rates for the American dollar was 298.4000 buying, 305.4000 selling; the British pound was 404.0034 buying, and 415.3452 selling, and the euro was 349.2739 buying, 360.4791 selling.
